items.title: 300 South Koreans detained at Hyundai plant in US to be released, says Seoul
items.standfirst: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...
items.content: Footage of raid by US immigration officials showed detained workers in handcuffs and with chains around their anklesSouth Korea announced on Sunday that the roughly 300 of its nationals detained during an immigration raid in Georgia would be released and flown home, as the sudden detention of workers appeared to strain the longstanding diplomatic and economic relationship between the two nations.Nearly 500 workers, among them at least 300 South Koreans and at least 23 Mexicans, were arrested at the Hyundai-LG battery plant in the city of Ellabell on Thursday. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

Continue reading...

South Korean officials negotiated a deal for the release of detained citizens.
The US agreed to release hundreds of South Koreans caught in the immigration raid.
The raid sparked shock and concern regarding US and South Korean relations.

items.title: Trump issues ‘last warning’ to Hamas to accept Gaza ceasefire deal
items.standfirst: President says ‘the Israelis have accepted my terms’ and urges release of hostages to secure peace agreementDonald Trump on Sunday issued what he called his “last warning” to Hamas, urging the Palestinian militant group to accept a deal to release hostages from Gaza.“The Israelis have accepted my Terms. It is time for Hamas to accept as well,” Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform. “I have warned Hamas about the consequences of not accepting. This is my last warning, there will not be another one!” Continue reading...

It is time for Hamas to accept as well,” Trump said in a post on his Truth Social platform. “I have warned Hamas about the consequences of not accepting. This is my last warning, there will not be another one!” Continue reading...

items.title: Japan's Shigeru Ishiba resigns after his party suffered a historic defeat in a summer election

items.content: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announced Sunday that he will resign, following growing calls from within his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July’s parliamentary election. Story by Catherine Viette.

items.content: The prime minister had struggled to inspire confidence as Japan faced economic headwinds.

items.title: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba resigns
items.standfirst: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba has resigned after pressure from within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the potential for a leadership vote against him.
items.content: Japan's prime minister Shigeru Ishiba has resigned after pressure from within his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and the potential for a leadership vote against him.

items.title: Japan PM Shigeru Ishiba to resign amid fallout from disastrous elections
items.standfirst: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...
items.content: Public broadcaster says prime minister has made decision to avoid divide within his Liberal Democratic partyJapan’s prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba, is to resign less than a year after taking office, throwing the country’s politics into turmoil and setting in motion a potentially messy contest to replace him as leader of the ruling Liberal Democratic party (LDP).The softly spoken centrist has presided over two disastrous elections since being elected to lead the LDP last autumn. In October, the party and its junior coalition partner Komeito lost their majority in the lower house and met the same fate in upper house elections this July. Continue reading...

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to resign
items.standfirst: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.
items.content: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has expressed his intention on Sunday to step down following growing calls from his party to take responsibility for a historic defeat in July's parliamentary election.(Image credit: Philip Fong)

items.title: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba to step down after clinching U.S. tariff deal
items.standfirst: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.
items.content: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has decided to resign to avoid a split within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, public broadcaster NHK said on Sunday.

The canonisation of Carlo Acutis, who died from leukaemia aged 15 in…

items.title: Pope Leo canonizes 'God's influencer,' the Catholic Church's first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St. Peter’s Square on Sunday. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports at the Vatican.
items.content: Pope Leo XIV declared 15-year-old Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint at an open-air Mass attended by tens of thousands of people in the Vatican’s St. Peter’s Square on Sunday. NBC News’ Claudio Lavanga reports at the Vatican.

items.title: Thousands flock to Vatican as teenager made first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.
items.content: Pope Leo canonises the London-born Italian boy nicknamed "God's influencer" for his online skills.

items.title: Carlo Acutis, ‘God’s influencer’ who died age 15, declared a saint by Pope Leo
items.standfirst: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...
items.content: London-born Italian, who died in 2006, built websites to spread Catholic teaching and is credited with two miraclesA London-born Italian teenage computer whiz who died in 2006 age 15, has been declared the Catholic church’s first millennial saint during an open-air mass in a packed St Peter’s Square.Carlo Acutis, who died of leukaemia, built multilingual websites to spread Catholic teaching, later earning him the nickname “God’s influencer”. He was canonised by Pope Leo XIV alongside Pier Giorgio Frassati, another young Catholic activist, who died a century ago. Continue reading...

items.title: Pope declares 'God's influencer' first millennial saint
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.
items.content: Tens of thousands of people gathered at the Vatican on Sunday as Pope Leo XIV proclaimed the Catholic Church's first millennial saint, Carlo Acutis, an Italian teenager dubbed "God's Influencer" for his efforts to spread the faith online. Details and by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Rome, Philip Willan.

items.title: Pope Leo declares Italian teen computer whiz a saint
items.standfirst: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.
items.content: Carlo Acutis, who who died of leukaemia aged 15, became the first Catholic saint of the millennial generation on Sunday, in a Vatican ceremony led by Pope Leo and attended by thousands of young worshippers. The pope also canonised another popular Italian figure who died young, Pier Giorgio Frassati.

clusters.title: Russia lands symbolic blow as largest aerial attack on Ukraine's capital shows Moscow's strategy
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Launches Massive Drone Attack on Ukraine's Capital

items.title: Russia lands symbolic blow as largest aerial attack on Ukraine's capital shows Moscow's strategy
items.standfirst: The smoke spiralling above Kyiv's Cabinet of Ministers building was a stark reminder of the brutal calculus underpinning Russia's war in Ukraine.
items.content: The smoke spiralling above Kyiv's Cabinet of Ministers building was a stark reminder of the brutal calculus underpinning Russia's war in Ukraine.

items.title: Ukraine government building damaged in large Russia aerial attack
items.standfirst: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.
items.content: Russia attacked Ukraine with 810 drones and decoys – the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, Ukraine's Air Force said.

items.title: Russia launches record mass drone attack on Ukraine
items.standfirst: Moscow’s forces fire 805 drones in one night, striking government building in Kyiv
items.content: Moscow’s forces fire 805 drones in one night, striking government building in Kyiv

items.title: Russia hits Ukraine with more that 800 drones and decoy drones in biggest-ever aerial barrage
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack since the war began, killing four people across the country and damaging a key government building. Russia attacked with 810 drones and decoys, Ukraine's air force said, adding it shot down 747 drones and four missiles. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Gulliver Cragg.

items.title: Record Russian drone attack pounds Ukraine, damaging government building
items.standfirst: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.
items.content: Russia hit Ukraine's capital with drone and missiles Sunday in the largest aerial attack on the country since the war began, killing at least two people and leaving smoke rising from the roof of a key government building. Story by Shirli Sitbon.

items.title: Watch: BBC at the scene of Ukrainian government building strike

items.content: One of Kyiv's main government buildings was hit in overnight missile and drone strikes by Russia.

ai_summary: Russia launched a large aerial attack on Kyiv, damaging a government building.
The attack involved over 800 drones and decoys, the largest of the war.
Ukraine's Air Force reported shooting down 747 drones and four missiles.
The attack resulted in casualties, with at least two people killed.
The BBC reported on the scene of the Ukrainian government building strike.

clusters.title: Tom Phillips shooting: NZ police search for children after fugitive father shot dead by police – latest updates
clusters.neutral_headline: New Zealand Police Kill Fugitive Father After Manhunt

items.title: Tom Phillips shooting: NZ police search for children after fugitive father shot dead by police – latest updates
items.standfirst: Fugitive father who has been on the run with his children for four years was shot by police after an attempted burglary of a building in Piopio. Police are now searching for two of his missing childrenFull report: Tom Phillips shot dead after attempted burglary, NZ police confirmThe mayor of Waitomo, John Robertson, told the Guardian this morning’s events were the worst possible outcome for the community.“I’m shattered, to be honest, and there will be many in the community that are devastated that this was the outcome after three and a half, four years,” he said.So it’s just devastating news. Really the worst outcome we could have expected.No day that goes by that I don’t think about all four of them.It hurts every time I see photos of the children and of you, and see some of your stuff that is still here, thinking what could have been if you had not gone away. Continue reading...
items.content: Fugitive father who has been on the run with his children for four years was shot by police after an attempted burglary of a building in Piopio. Police are now searching for two of his missing childrenFull report: Tom Phillips shot dead after attempted burglary, NZ police confirmThe mayor of Waitomo, John Robertson, told the Guardian this morning’s events were the worst possible outcome for the community.“I’m shattered, to be honest, and there will be many in the community that are devastated that this was the outcome after three and a half, four years,” he said.So it’s just devastating news. Really the worst outcome we could have expected.No day that goes by that I don’t think about all four of them.It hurts every time I see photos of the children and of you, and see some of your stuff that is still here, thinking what could have been if you had not gone away. Continue reading...

items.title: Tom Phillips, fugitive father on run with children for nearly four years, shot dead by NZ police in exchange of fire
items.standfirst: Phillips, who has been on the run with his children for four years, was shot by police after officers came under fire while investigating burglary in Piopio, authorities saidNew Zealand police search for missing children after shooting – latest updatesA fugitive father who had been hiding in New Zealand’s rugged wilderness with his three children for nearly four years has been shot dead by police during an armed burglary, police confirmed on Monday.Tom Phillips fled into the Waikato wilderness with his children Ember, now 9, Maverick, 10, and Jayda, 12, just before Christmas 2021, following a dispute with their mother. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Fugitive father on the run with children for nearly four years 'shot dead by police'
items.standfirst: A man who had been hiding with his three children in the New Zealand wilderness for nearly four years is believed to have been shot dead after an armed confrontation with police.
items.content: A man who had been hiding with his three children in the New Zealand wilderness for nearly four years is believed to have been shot dead after an armed confrontation with police.

ai_summary: A fugitive father was shot dead by police after an attempted burglary.
The father had been on the run with his children for nearly four years.

items.title: American influencer released from Chilean Antarctic air base after 2 months
items.standfirst: American influencer and pilot Ethan Guo has been released to mainland Chile after being stuck at an Antarctic air base for two months. The 20-year-old was attempting to become the youngest person to fly solo to all seven continents when Chilean authorities accused him of landing illegally on their Antarctic territory.
